video_description: A video review of the Lenovo IdeaPad K1 Android tablet. Check out our full review at: http://www.mobiletechreview.com/tablets/Lenovo-IdeaPad-K1.htm  It sports the usual Honeycomb specs: a 10.1" capacitive touch screen, 1GHz Nvidia Tegra 2 dual core CPU, a gig of RAM, 32 gigs of flash storage, WiFi, Bluetooth, a GPS and dual cameras.
title: Lenovo IdeaPad K1 Review

comments.text: Bought one 3 days ago on sale at best buy for $350. Returned it yesterday. The screen has lines running lengthwise. The lines are every 1/4 inch in rows, very strange, likely a defective unit but to me shows the poor production quality of lenovo. That aside, the brightness, contrast, and viewing angle is below par﻿ even for a non IPS display. Other poor design was the top edge, its 2 pieces slapped together with sharp edges and one piece is plastic other metal, poorly designed and made product.

comments.text: i want to get this for school as well as entertainment, im kinda a idiot when it comes to this kind of stuff so i have one question. can you hook up a keyboard (maybe through the bluetooth?) and do word processing with this? ﻿

comments.text: Yes on both. You can﻿ use a Bluetooth keyboard, and use Docs To Go for word processing.
comments.author: MobileTechReview

comments.text: Check out the ThinkPad tablet which has﻿ dual digitizer that's better for taking notes.
comments.author: MobileTechReview

comments.text: The IdeaPad has a capacitive touch screen. You can certainly take notes, but﻿ not as effective as the ThinkPad tablet's screen. If you put your hand on the screen while taking notes on a capacitive touch screen, it will get confused. An active digitizer touch screen will know you are using a pen and won't do anything if your hands touch the screen when the pen is in use.
comments.author: MobileTechReview

comments.text: I love the depth of your reviews. But I have a question, Looking at this tablet on Lenovo's website, I see that all 3 of their tablets have the feature they call "Built-in mobile broadband powered by Gobi™ technology by Qualcomm® provides you on-the-go anytime-anywhere internet access."  Does this mean I'll be able to use﻿ broadband internet on the go? What is gobi? Does this feature come with the tablets or cost a monthly fee? I'd like to know before I purchase. Thanks.
comments.author: Janeen Tuesday

comments.text: Lenovo uses their specs in a broad way. The IdeaPad K1 we reviewed here doesn't have 3G, but for Lenovo tablets in general, if a carrier wants to﻿ offer it, Lenovo can put Gobi in for 3G support.
comments.author: MobileTechReview

comments.text: Also the Gobi modem option is available﻿ now for the ThinkPad Tablet.
comments.author: MobileTechReview
